status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
As a cloud admin I would like to deploy the Eucalyptus Management Console in a cloud-compatible VM so that I can provide a console that easily scales to meet the demands of my users/customers.

Delivering the user console inside an image (exactly same as imaging, ELB, etc., workers); so no work is called for w/in the console.  

This achieves several things which are important: 
- consistent with delivery of other services
- no configuration of the console required (all configuration can be automated w/ an instance)
- no artificial restriction on console dependencies
- console having an identity in the system — through a console account and IAM instance profile based credentials — to call euca:service operations

These are those that apply to problems existing today.  It makes possible things which are not possible otherwise:
- horizontal scalability
- isolated network environment w/ system enforced network restrictions
- self-configuration when the system changes (because of UFS)
- domain naming support for a fixed console endpoint (e.g., console.eucalyptus.subdomain.com)
- load balancing requests w/ ELB
- auto scaling based on console controlled triggers 
- possibility of non-trivial topologies for the console (e.g., w/ a shared service of some kind)

List of stuff that can/should be done to support this...
- Make the console available in an image, supported by the service image lifecycle management features, in a Eucalyptus cloud.
- Push for improvements in the service image management features before offering the ability to deploy the console in a Eucalyptus cloud.
fields.summary: Support the ability to deploy the Console in an autoscaling-capable cloud

comments.body:
[~kgill], can you clarify which is the scope for this story:
* "provide a console that easily scales"
OR
* the list of stuff that can be done

I assume it is the first, and read the second as benefit.  How far is this intended to go in 4.2?

After investigation and testing, here are thing things necessary to run the console at scale (w/o memcached).

#  create ELB (load balancer), initially with no listeners since we'll need an SSL cert to configure our HTTPS listener. Define health check to use HTTPS/443 and path of "/". Select the zone or zones you wish to use for your scaling group(s).
# create an SSL cert using the ELB public DNS name, or configure a DNS record pointing to the ELB and use that DNS name in your SSL cert.
# Add a listener to the ELB for HTTP/443 on the client and instance side, using the SSL cert you just created.
# create security group for scaling group (console servers). Open port port 443 to incoming traffic from the security group being used by the ELB.
# create launch config using attached cloud-init script in user-data. Use a CentOS 6 image. We can use m1.medium, but our min server spec states 4 cores and 8GB of memory, so m3.2xlarge w/ 4 cores and 4G memory is closest to that. Be sure to modify the 10th line in the cloud-init script to use the cloud back-end FQDN in place of the name already there. Near the bottom of the cloud-init script are 2 random keys. You should generate your own to ensure some uniqueness in your session cookie encryption. On CentOS, run "cat /dev/urandom | tr -dc 'a-zA-Z0-9' | fold -w 32 | head -n 1" to create a new random 32 character string.
# create an autoscaling group that uses this launch configuration and the ELB. You might want to set a propagating tag to label instances in this autoscaling group. If you want to manually scale this group, you can start with min/desired/max set to 1, but adjust desired/max to reflect the number of instances you'd like. A better way is to set up scaling policies, one to scale up, another to scale down based on CPU load. Sustained CPU load over 90% is usually a good sign you want to add another instance. Sustained CPU load under 40% likely means you can remove an instance.

At this point, you will see 1 instance being launched and in a couple of minutes, it will show healthy and "in-service" in the ELB, at which point, you can start using the console.
[~ccassler], please check out the steps [~dkavanagh] documented int he previous step and see if they're correct...

[~jloza], [~dkavanagh]: I have responded to each step below:
# We probably want to reword this since we can't create an ELB without the default HTTP listener on port 80.
# This sounds fine.  Do we want to include a link or scripts on the process for creating an SSL cert?
# This sounds fine.
# This should be a security group for the launch config shouldn't it?  If the group isn't created here, it can also be done when they create a launch config.  We will also need a keypair and we would probably want to open port 22(ssh) access for trouble-shooting (but that can be optional or added later if needed).
# This sounds good. 
# Nothing to add here.

[~ccassler]
 1. I agree. In fact, leaving port 80 listener in place is great because it allows our port 80 redirector in nginx to function (tested this)
 2. Agreed. Is there something simple we could reference? I have a gist that shows it: https://gist.github.com/dkavanagh/0945573dc13f1328ca72
 4. yes, sorry, that should say "launch config".
Sounds like we need a linked bug to not allow the removal of the listener on port 80 that we define by default in the GUI?

We should not restrict the addition or removal of listeners. For console deployment, we should leave the port  80 listener which lets the port 80 redirector to work. That doesn't mean it always needs to be there for every ELB.

[~dkavanagh], [~jloza]: Sorry, I meant we can't create a Load Balancer without a listener.  It doesn't have to be on port 80 but there has to be at least one.  Having said that, would it be better to just have the user create the SSL cert in step 3 before creating the LB?  Then they can just include the SSL listener when they create the LB and won't have to go back to re-configure the LB later.

I'm sorry, I should have been clearer.
We should create the ELB, initially with the default port 80 listener. We'll want that anyway for handling port 80 redirect.
We can't create the SSL cert until we know the ELB's FQDN, so that 443 listener can only be added *after* the elb is created and *after* the cert is generated. Make sense?

This should be a good roll-up of comments.
 # create ELB (load balancer), leave the default port 80 listener and don't add the port 443 listener yet since we'll need an SSL cert first. Define health check to use HTTPS/443 and path of "/". Select the zone or zones you wish to use for your scaling group(s).
 # create an SSL cert using the ELB public DNS name, or configure a DNS record pointing to the ELB and use that DNS name in your SSL cert. (http://docs.aws.amazon.com/ElasticLoadBalancing/latest/DeveloperGuide/ssl-server-cert.html#create-cert)
 # Add a listener to the ELB for HTTP/443 on the client and instance side, using the SSL cert you just created.
 # create security group for scaling group (console servers) which you will use in your launch configuration. Open port ports 80 and 443 to incoming traffic from the security group being used by the ELB.
 # create launch config using attached cloud-init script in user-data. Use a CentOS 6 image. We can use m1.medium, but our min server spec states 4 cores and 8GB of memory, so m3.2xlarge w/ 4 cores and 4G memory is closest to that. Be sure to modify the 10th line in the cloud-init script to use the cloud back-end FQDN in place of the name already there. Near the bottom of the cloud-init script are 2 random keys. You should generate your own to ensure some uniqueness in your session cookie encryption. On CentOS, run "cat /dev/urandom | tr -dc 'a-zA-Z0-9' | fold -w 32 | head -n 1" to create a new random 32 character string.
 # create an autoscaling group that uses this launch configuration and the ELB. You might want to set a propagating tag to label instances in this autoscaling group. If you want to manually scale this group, you can start with min/desired/max set to 1, but adjust desired/max to reflect the number of instances you'd like. A better way is to set up scaling policies, one to scale up, another to scale down based on CPU load. Sustained CPU load over 90% is usually a good sign you want to add another instance. Sustained CPU load under 40% likely means you can remove an instance.

At this point, you will see 1 instance being launched and in a couple of minutes, it will show healthy and "in-service" in the ELB, at which point, you can start using the console.
[~dkavanagh], [~jloza]: Okay, these steps looks good to me.
This ticket is done.  DOC-1671 was created for this issue.
